data.text: Does it worth to carry a foldable camping chair on a cycle tour?
Do you feel it is worthwhile bringing a light foldable camping chair on a cycle tour when you plan on camping?
Yes! But it doesn't matter what anyone else thinks..... It only matters what *you* think
data.author: Hobbes On Tour

data.text: Yes it sure does , when tired of pedaling and the tent is up its so nice to sit in a Chair with a homebrew , memoiring the past etappe üòâ
data.author: Stefan Van Zurk

data.text: Absolutely after riding for hours on end you want to relax don't you?
data.author: Craig Cartner

data.text: Yes definitely!
data.author: Alex Baker

data.text: It's priceless! I use the Helinox Chair Zero. At 1lbs (450g), it's no weight at all and way worth it's price
data.author: Adir Sharon

data.text: Yes
data.author: Henriette Henriette

data.text: Yes. I've got a Helinox Ground Chair, low enough to be useful inside a tent as well as outside. About 640g I think from memory. It's a real bit of luxury on a tour.
data.author: Phil Metcalfe

data.text: yes
data.author: Susan Kopczynski Jostrom

data.text: Absolutely.
data.author: Philip Lenaghan

data.text: Nope. Don't want any extra weight. Been all day sitting on my arse üòÇü§£
data.author: Rachel Katherine

data.text: Have fun standing.
data.author: Eric Walters

data.text: always do after a day in the saddle and when I'm done the floor is an amazing invention üòä
data.author: Rachel Katherine

data.text: First trip with them. I prefer to sit on the ground but my partner loves the chair. Aldi $40 aus. I'm thinking of ditching mine to save weight... But sometimes it is perfect.
data.author: Rosalyn Newman

data.text: For sure idc about the weight that much becouse of the comfort it brings while cooking in the morning waking up sitting around campfire or during a break letter the behind rest some during lunch whip it out sit and eat i did have to swap to a tall back chair since the normal helinox chair was too low to the ground which made my knees hurt
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: Yup even prefer the chair in a cabin
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: Chair and umbrella.
data.author: Clyde Slade

data.text: Abso-F___ing-lutely.
data.author: Eric Walters

data.text: I bring a bamboo mat ..I love it. I sit, lay down
data.author: Leslie Carvery

data.text: YES!
data.author: Karl Stari

data.text: That's one of the reasons I use bucket panniers: you can use them a a table and a chair in the wild.
data.author: Brian Huntley

data.text: I bought a BIG agnes skyline chair, weighs in at 765gram but can easily take my weight with no fear (110kg) super easy to put up and down and really comfy. Used it nearly every day this trip....got a very'colourfull' one...30qid cheaper than plain ones..at least I know it's mine. It's called a skyline ul.
data.author: Robert Wheeldon

data.text: I second this. The chair sits a little higher off the ground and super sturdy!! I have never traveled with a chair until recently and the days I use it, I‚Äôm so thankful I have it!!
data.author: Kim Johnson

data.text: I never took one to a bike tour, but I always regretted not to do so. The problem is finding one which is light, small and still comfortable enough.
data.author: √ñzkal √ñzsoy

data.text: Helinox UL is 450g (1lbs) or Big Agnes - slightly heavier but sits higher
data.author: Adir Sharon

data.text: they look right, but just checked, cost a fortune. :(
data.author: √ñzkal √ñzsoy

data.text: it's worth it for long tours. I'm touring over 4 years now with a few months break in winters. It makes a world of a difference. Wait till you find it on sale. I bought mine for $99 on end of season sale
data.author: Adir Sharon

data.text: thanks> I will check. ;)
data.author: √ñzkal √ñzsoy

data.text: I use a thermarest sleeping mat chair converter. Turns your sleeping mat into a chair
data.author: Mike Hughes

data.text: I've hiked with a helinox when I had to carry it lol. Definitely worthwhile if free camping and you're not comfortable sitting on the ground.
data.author: Alison Emily Baker

data.text: I have a helinox chair but would not take it on a cycle tour. They are light and small for chairs but even so their bulk is a big issue on a bike. I take a bum sized square of 10 mm thick closed cell foam. Fits easily in a pannier.
data.author: Ian Houghton

data.text: I have a hip impingement so yes. I was so excited to learn about backpacking chairs.
data.author: Gerald Prokop

data.text: Absolutely.
data.author: Bruce Richards

data.text: Id rather bring a hammock you can lay down in it or set in it kinda like a chair.i also bring a very small memory foam pillow that actually could be used to make any hard surface soft to set on.
data.author: Norbe Alatorre

data.text: Yes, yes, and thrice yes. After being perched on a saddle for several hours, pumping pedals, it is nice to take the weight off of your feet and sit bones, spread the load over the rest of your bum and support your back. There are lots of clones of the Helinox chairs out there that are not as light, but won't leave your purse/wallet light after purchase either.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Yes...yesss...yessss...ooohhhhh....yesssssüòÜ
data.author: Jewella C Miranda

data.text: Weighing 500 g, no more.
data.author: Ango Radus

data.text: If you have room, bring one!
data.author: Ed Weingarten

data.text: Depends on where you are touring - but it is a thing I regretted not having with me in Europe. While there is a lot to be said for campgrounds there - they generally don‚Äôt provide anywhere for tent campers to sit - like no picnic tables or the like. At least in my experience.
data.author: Elizabeth Cage

data.text: Never leave home without it
data.author: Paul Wright

data.text: Another vote for the Helinox üëç
data.author: Lynne Sixtyodd Roberts

data.text: Thanks everyone! Very helpful.
data.author: Rhonda Klann Leduc

data.text: Definately a good idea for you oftentimes bump into other campers that have them, and you end up looking up to them and creaking your neck, as apposed to looking them in the eye as you do in 'normal' Western Society...A good thing to remember is if it's a little cross legged stool type, make sure you get one with a 'bottom' bit that prevents the legs getting stuck and sinking in the ground. This can be quite infuriating...
data.author: David Eldred

data.text: I love my helinox ground chair
data.author: Alison Wheeler

data.text: Is it solid enough to carry a big, strong guy weighing 100kg ?
data.author: Anders Hansen

data.text: the Big Agnes is!
data.author: Kim Johnson

data.text: 110% totally worthwhile. After a long days ride, the last thing you wanna do is be uncomfortable while you cook dinner. This was a lifesaver! Sea To Summit do an 'airchair' which uses a folded up airmatress, worked well with an inflatable pillow (if you like lumbar support).
data.author: Ellen Joy

data.text: Helinox üëçüëç
data.author: James Mckoy

data.text: I always bring my Helinox Ground Zero. One pound weight penalty but totally worth it after riding all day
data.author: Michael Shireman

data.text: Definitely. It is a game changer in terms of comfort when wild camping and doubles as a place to put things while you pack up, particularly if it is raining or wet.
data.author: Grahame Joy

data.text: Yes
data.author: Mandy Farmer

data.text: Depends on your body. For those accustomed to sitting on the ground can take pleasure in not carrying extra weight
data.author: Benjamin Moravec

data.text: Absolutely. Loved my chair
data.author: David Thornbury

data.text: We have helinox ultralight! Really like them!
data.author: Lenie Hollants

data.text: I think yes. I carry a chair with bicycle touring and canoe touring.
data.author: Kawanta Lewis

data.text: Yes!! We always do ! A lit of comfort for o,5 kilo
data.author: Ilse van der Auwera
Rhonda Klann Leduc

data.text: I ended up buying a trekology camping chair for $60 CND. We‚Äôll see how it holds up.
data.author: Rhonda Klann Leduc

data.text: I Carry one All Times
data.author: Ted Messer

data.text: Game changer! Using a Helinox chair excellent off the ground great in hot dusty conditions. Makes cooking and reading a pleasure
data.author: David Renton

data.text: Hmmm... Taking a break standing. Or sitting on the ground... Or... I'm enjoying my chair right now. Yes.
data.author: Hank Rowe

data.text: It depends on how light want to go. I do. But I like a bit of comfort and I'm not in a race just touring. I go a travel chair that comes it's own little bag- they're everywhere. But nice.
data.author: Marc Mac Leod

data.text: We used a camp stool which meant you could sit on it and kneel at the same time. Ideal for cooking and fixing you bike. Only issue was the weight but it was worth it
data.author: Tim Bridgman
